data.title: Error: Could not create an input method
data.body:
<!--

Have you read Atom's Code of Conduct? By filing an Issue, you are expected to comply with it, including treating everyone with respect: https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md

Do you want to ask a question? Are you looking for support? The Atom message board is the best place for getting support: https://discuss.atom.io

-->

### Prerequisites

* [X] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

After upgrading to atom 1.14.1, atom crashes.
I have tried removing the config completely and reinstalling the whole package but it wont work.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Open atom editor

**Expected behavior:** [What you expect to happen]
Editor shows up.

**Actual behavior:** [What actually happens]
Chrome-like console shows up with error. Also, a message popped up which says the editor crashed and please report the issue here.
Behavior is the same in safe mode.

**Reproduces how often:** [What percentage of the time does it reproduce?]
100%

### Versions

Atom    : 1.14.1
Electron: 1.3.13
Chrome  : 52.0.2743.82
Node    : 6.5.0

apm  1.15.3
npm  3.10.5
node 4.4.5 x64
python 2.7.12+
git 2.9.3


Running on Ubuntu 16.10.

### Additional Information

Any additional information, configuration or data that might be necessary to reproduce the issue.

1.10.2 version was the old version i used. It runs perfectly fine on my computer.

The error log: 
> Error: Could not create an input method.
    at Error (native)
    at Object.<anonymous> (/usr/share/atom/resources/app.asar/node_modules/keyboard-layout/lib/keyboard-layout.js:9:17)
    at Module._compile (/usr/share/atom/resources/app.asar/src/native-compile-cache.js:109:30)
    at Object.value [as .js] (/usr/share/atom/resources/app.asar/src/compile-cache.js:216:21)
    at Module.load (module.js:473:32)
    at tryModuleLoad (module.js:432:12)
    at Function.Module._load (module.js:424:3)
    at Module.require (module.js:483:17)
    at require (/usr/share/atom/resources/app.asar/src/native-compile-cache.js:50:27)
    at Object.<anonymous> (/usr/share/atom/resources/app.asar/node_modules/atom-keymap/lib/helpers.js:6:20)
    at Object.<anonymous> (/usr/share/atom/resources/app.asar/node_modules/atom-keymap/lib/helpers.js:372:4)
    at Module._compile (/usr/share/atom/resources/app.asar/src/native-compile-cache.js:109:30)
    at Object.value [as .js] (/usr/share/atom/resources/app.asar/src/compile-cache.js:216:21)
    at Module.load (module.js:473:32)
    at tryModuleLoad (module.js:432:12)
    at Function.Module._load (module.js:424:3)
    at Module.require (module.js:483:17)
    at require (/usr/share/atom/resources/app.asar/src/native-compile-cache.js:50:27)
    at Object.<anonymous> (/usr/share/atom/resources/app.asar/node_modules/atom-keymap/lib/key-binding.js:4:10)
    at Object.<anonymous> (/usr/share/atom/resources/app.asar/node_modules/atom-keymap/lib/key-binding.js:129:4)
    at Module._compile (/usr/share/atom/resources/app.asar/src/native-compile-cache.js:109:30)
    at Object.value [as .js] (/usr/share/atom/resources/app.asar/src/compile-cache.js:216:21)
    at Module.load (module.js:473:32)
    at tryModuleLoad (module.js:432:12)
    at Function.Module._load (module.js:424:3)
    at Module.require (module.js:483:17)
    at require (/usr/share/atom/resources/app.asar/src/native-compile-cache.js:50:27)
    at Object.<anonymous> (/usr/share/atom/resources/app.asar/node_modules/atom-keymap/lib/keymap-manager.js:17:11)
    at Object.<anonymous> (/usr/share/atom/resources/app.asar/node_modules/atom-keymap/lib/keymap-manager.js:639:4)
    at Module._compile (/usr/share/atom/resources/app.asar/src/native-compile-cache.js:109:30)


This is my first time reporting an issue, i am fine to provide extra information if needed. Thanks!

UPDATE: 1.13.0 works fine.

data.title: Atom icon doesn't override pinned icon in Windows 10 taskbar
data.body: Windows 10, started happening in 1.14.1: if the atom launcher is pinned to the taskbar, when the program launches it creates another icon that doesn't override it. It's not that big a problem but when shortcutting with <kbd>Windows key</kbd> + <kbd>#</kbd> (number of the application on the taskbar), it will open a new window instead on focusing on the one you were working on.

data.title: [OS X] File -> Open... menu command does nothing if there are no windows open
data.body:
<!--

Have you read Atom's Code of Conduct? By filing an Issue, you are expected to comply with it, including treating everyone with respect: https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md

Do you want to ask a question? Are you looking for support? The Atom message board is the best place for getting support: https://discuss.atom.io

-->

### Prerequisites

* [X] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

[Description of the issue]

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Open Atom on Mac OS X
2. Close the blank window that atom creates on startup
3. Try using the File -> Open... command, nothing happens
4. Open a new blank window using File -> New Window
5. File -> Open... now correctly opens a file selection dialog.

**Expected behavior:** [What you expect to happen]
That File -> Open... would produce a file selection dialog when atom has no windows currently open but is still running.

**Actual behavior:** [What actually happens]
No dialog appears.

**Reproduces how often:** [What percentage of the time does it reproduce?]
100%

### Versions

```
atom --version
Atom    : 1.9.9
Electron: 0.37.8
Chrome  : 49.0.2623.75
Node    : 5.10.0
```
```
apm  1.10.0
npm  2.13.3
node 0.10.40
python 2.7.10
git 2.10.1
```


### Additional Information
N/A

data.title: Atom breaking on index.html file that contains newrelic single page application monitoring
data.body:
### Prerequisites

* [x] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

Atom is breaking on an index.html file that contains a newrelic single page application javascript snippet consistently.

### Steps to Reproduce

Open atom and open a lengthy index.html file with newrelic
Atom freezes and the editor stops working.
Error pops up after a bit stating "Editor is not responding" and options to force close or wait.

**Expected behavior:** [What you expect to happen]
Atom opens the index file without an issue

**Actual behavior:** [What actually happens]
Atom crashes

**Reproduces how often:** [What percentage of the time does it reproduce?]
100% of time

### Versions
Atom    : 1.14.0
Electron: 1.3.13
Chrome  : 52.0.2743.82
Node    : 6.5.0
apm  1.15.3
npm  3.10.5
node 4.4.5 x64
python 2.7.11
git 2.10.1

OSX 10.12.3
MacBook Pro (Retina, 15-inch, Mid 2015)
2.5 GHz Intel Core i7
16 GB 1600 MHz DDR3
AMD Radeon R9 M370X 2048 MB
Intel Iris Pro 1536 MB

### Additional Information

I have completely removed atom and deleted all the following files:

delete the app from the Applications folder
delete the invisible .atom directory from the home folder
delete the /usr/local/bin/atom tool
delete the /usr/local/bin/apm tool
delete the ~/Library/Preferences/com.github.atom.plist file

I then reinstalled the latest version of atom. This happens from scratch.

This issue did not occur on the exact same file before the most recent update.

Issue does not occur on sublime or vim. Index.html file is 30kb

Index.html file includes newrelic single page app configuration, which is likely the longest piece of code in the file. Other simple html files open on atom without an issue.

data.title: Use <details> elements in releases
data.body:
Please change the [release descriptions](https://github.com/atom/atom/releases) to use `<details>` elements so we don’t have to scroll through a list of every change.

For example:

<details><summary>Details</summary>

> **Markdown** works if you put a *blank line* between the start tags and the content.
</details>

data.title: can't open big text files
data.body:
1. Open big file (access log of apache)


**Atom Version**: 1.13.1
**Electron Version**: 1.3.13
**System**: Windows 7
**Thrown From**: Atom Core


### Stack Trace

Uncaught RangeError: Invalid string length

```
At C:\Users\<User>\Downloads\atom-windows\Atom\resources\app.asar\node_modules\text-buffer\node_modules\pathwatcher\lib\file.js:310

RangeError: Invalid string length
    at Array.join (native)
    at ReadStream.<anonymous> (C:\Users\<User>\Downloads\atom-windows\Atom\resources\app.asar\node_modules\text-buffer\node_modules\pathwatcher\lib\file.js:310:38)
    at emitNone (events.js:91:20)
    at ReadStream.emit (events.js:185:7)
    at endReadableNT (_stream_readable.js:974:12)
    at _combinedTickCallback (internal/process/next_tick.js:74:11)
    at process._tickCallback (internal/process/next_tick.js:98:9)
```


### Config
default from the zip file

### Installed Packages

data.title: find-next-selected(Ctrl-F3) command work after initial calling find(Ctrl-f) command
data.body:
### Description of problem

I opened some file with Atom text editor. After that I tried to find word that cursor is standing in using `Ctrl-F3`. But it didn't work. I call find window (`Ctrl-f`) and closed it. After this operation I could use `Ctrl-F3` command freely.

* [ ] `find-next-selected` command should work at start although `find` command initially called

data.title: Windows 10 - Bash (Ubuntu) | How to run Atom build with bash command?
data.body:
<!--

Have you read Atom's Code of Conduct? By filing an Issue, you are expected to comply with it, including treating everyone with respect: https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md

Do you want to ask a question? Are you looking for support? The Atom message board is the best place for getting support: https://discuss.atom.io

-->

### Prerequisites

* [X] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

I got a lot of problems when I try to run commands on Atom to "bash.exe". No matter what extension I use.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Enable "Bash Ubuntu" for Windows 10.
2. Setup compiler for my application on "Bash Ubuntu".
3. Test from "bash.exe" and "powershell.exe". Everything work ok.
4. Install Atom.
5. Create an runner on Atom.
6. Get msg "Erro: 0x80070057"

**Expected behavior:** Expected the same result as Powershell:
![j1zfg](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/2138276/22767136/acf148be-ee60-11e6-9d15-ceb6ce3d1eb6.jpg)

**Actual behavior:** But I  got this error:
![5abft](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/2138276/22767156/c5bb38f0-ee60-11e6-8951-c57547d38e9c.jpg)

**Reproduces how often:** always happen.

### Versions
Atom    : 1.15.0-beta0
Electron: 1.3.13
Chrome  : 52.0.2743.82
Node    : 6.5.0

apm  1.15.3
npm  3.10.5
node 4.4.5 x64
python
git 2.9.0.windows.
visual studio 2015

Windows 10 Pro (with all lastest updates)

### Additional Information

I got the same problem with any extension I use.

I wrote an question at Stack Overflow too:
http://stackoverflow.com/questions/42121927/windows-10-bash-ubuntu-how-to-run-atom-build-on-bash

#### I found two things can help
- Disable Legacy Mode on Powershell (https://github.com/Microsoft/BashOnWindows/issues/7)
- Use Powershell ISE (https://github.com/Microsoft/BashOnWindows/issues/430)

data.title: Atom 1.15.0 Beta0 Keep Pulling updates 1.14.0 (stable channel?)
data.body:
I just update my Atom beta to 1.15.0, but I notice that the squirrel icon won't go away. When I click in and check, I saw Atom trying to pull update 1.14.0 which I assume it's from the stable channel. No matter how may times I click install and restart, the updates just won't go away.

For that, I did a clean installation of Atom beta, just to find nothing changes as shown in the screenshot below. I wiped out everything and haven't installed any packages.

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/17170199/22764405/accd397a-eebe-11e6-8496-d627722235e6.png)

data.title: Atom stops and cpu is 100% with some kind of file
data.body:
<!--

Have you read Atom's Code of Conduct? By filing an Issue, you are expected to comply with it, including treating everyone with respect: https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md

Do you want to ask a question? Are you looking for support? The Atom message board is the best place for getting support: https://discuss.atom.io

-->

### Prerequisites

* [X] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

Atom stops running and the CPU is 100% opening javascript source: http://pastebin.com/dJ9Dsu4M

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Copy the source code from http://pastebin.com/dJ9Dsu4M and save as a js file
2. Open the downloaded file

**Expected behavior:** Opening and editing the file normally

**Actual behavior:** Atom editor breaks and CPU frequency is 100%

**Reproduces how often:** 100%

### Versions

1.12.6

### Additional Information

Any additional information, configuration or data that might be necessary to reproduce the issue.

data.title: Default file encoding for python interpreter.
data.body: Is there a configuration file in Atom where I can specific the default encoding of python file? In VSCode, I can use `settings.json` file. I what to find a way to prevent writing ```python # -*-coding: utf-8-*- ``` in every file。 I'm using mac, The same file contains just this line code: ```python print("中文") ``` runs correctly in both VSCode and terminal, but there will be an error when using Atom ``` SyntaxError: Non-ASCII character '\xe4' in file ``` I'm new in Python and I've google a lot but no result.

data.title: [Beta 1.14.0] APM or github packages and Portable mode
data.body:
<!--

Have you read Atom's Code of Conduct? By filing an Issue, you are expected to comply with it, including treating everyone with respect: https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md

Do you want to ask a question? Are you looking for support? The Atom message board is the best place for getting support: https://discuss.atom.io

-->

### Prerequisites

* [X] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode => **Issue about APM**
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/ => **Issue about APM**
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages => **Issue about APM**

### Description
Trying to run APM in portable mode on Windows cannot be done, at least simply!

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Neither Atom nor APM are on the "PATH" and should be run on their respective folders
2. APM install <githubpackage> is able to install that github package but in the "classic" .atom folder: C:\Users\myself\.atom

**Expected behavior:** [What you expect to happen]
- Being able to run APM from Atom folder
- github package installed in the .atom folder alongside Atom.exe folder

**Actual behavior:** [What actually happens]
- Need to call resources\app\apm\bin\apm
- github package installed in %USERPROFILE%\.atom

**Reproduces how often:** [What percentage of the time does it reproduce?]
100%

### Versions
atom --version
```
Atom    : 1.14.0-beta4
Electron: 1.3.13
Chrome  : 52.0.2743.82
Node    : 6.5.0
```
apm --version
```
apm  1.15.3
npm  3.10.5
node 4.4.5 ia32
python 3.5.2
git 2.10.1.windows.1
visual studio
```

### Additional Information
None

data.title: Atom keeps trying to wrap long lines on markdown file causing text to blink
data.body:
<!--

Have you read Atom's Code of Conduct? By filing an Issue, you are expected to comply with it, including treating everyone with respect: https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md

Do you want to ask a question? Are you looking for support? The Atom message board is the best place for getting support: https://discuss.atom.io

-->

### Prerequisites

* [x] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

When I open an specific file (described below) with an specific windows size (see screencap) atom will try to accommodate the text by wrapping the long lines, then revert it and try again,resulting in the text alternating between this too states in a loop. The bottom half of the text will show and disappear while the top is being rearranged.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Open this file on atom https://github.com/docker-library/wordpress/blob/d8e5577dcc7096d2b694dda433e2b5c7c4561a82/README.md
2. If the text is still, resize the window until it reproduces the bug.

**Expected behavior:** 
The text should be rendered and stay still until the window is resized.

**Actual behavior:** 
The text will "blink" between these three states.
![bug](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/921798/22718325/e6cf5998-ed86-11e6-864b-f93cbe79ad14.gif)

**Reproduces how often:** 
100%

### Versions

Atom    : 1.13.1
Electron: 1.3.13
Chrome  : 52.0.2743.82
Node    : 6.5.0

### Additional Information

Any additional information, configuration or data that might be necessary to reproduce the issue.

data.title: Store represented directory paths directly on AtomWindow in main process
data.body:
Fixes #13761

Previously, when adding a window, we were unable to read its current project paths out of the hash of the URL during window initialization because the window still considered itself to be loading. Rather than fixing this issue, we decided to completely eliminate the sharing of state between processes in the window.location and instead switch to cached synchronous RPC for the loadSettings and a dedicated RPC-based mechanism for the project paths.

🍐 'd with @maxbrunsfeld

data.title: Unable to save a CPU Profile
data.body: ### Prerequisites * [x] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following: * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/ * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages ### Description A security error is produced when attempting to collect a CPU Profile through the developer tools in Atom. ### Steps to Reproduce 1. Launch Atom in your local atom repository 2. Press Alt+Cmd+I to open the Developer Tools 3. Click the Profiles tab in the Developer Tools 1. Ensure "Record JavaScript CPU Profile" is selected 1. Click Start 1. Do a couple random things in the editor 1. Click Stop 1. Observe that a SecurityError regarding temporary storage is displayed 1. Click the Save link next to the new profile record 1. Save to `~/Downloads` 1. Get info on the new `*.cpuprofile` file **Expected behavior:** The `cpuprofile` file to be longer than zero bytes **Actual behavior:** The `cpuprofile` file is always zero bytes ### Versions ``` Atom : 1.15.0-dev-ae9d949ee Electron: 1.3.13 Chrome : 52.0.2743.82 Node : 6.5.0 ``` I also reproduced this using v1.13.1 and v1.14.0-beta4. ### Additional Information

data.title: Opening a new window switches workspace and raises first window (Ubuntu)
data.body:
<!--

Have you read Atom's Code of Conduct? By filing an Issue, you are expected to comply with it, including treating everyone with respect: https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md

Do you want to ask a question? Are you looking for support? The Atom message board is the best place for getting support: https://discuss.atom.io

-->

### Prerequisites

* [X ] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

When opening a second (new) atom window on a different workspace, the first opened window gets focused for a short moment before the new window opens.
First of all this raises the first window (if e.g. minimized) but also switches the workspace to the workspace where the first window is positioned.
I have reproduced this with Ubuntu 14.04 and Ubuntu 16.10, opening a new window with e.g.
`atom --safe --clear-window-state -n .`


### Steps to Reproduce

1. Open the first window on a given workspace (workspace A) and minimize the atom window.
2. Switch workspace to an other workspace (workspace B).
3. Open a new atom window.

**Expected behavior:** 
A new atom window opening on the workspace B.
The first window on workspace A being still minimized.

**Actual behavior:**
The workspace switches to workspace A and the first window is no longer minimized.

**Reproduces how often:**
Every time so far.

### Versions
Atom    : 1.13.1
Electron: 1.3.13
Chrome  : 52.0.2743.82
Node    : 6.5.0

Linux  : 4.4.0-62-generic Ubuntu 14.04 with Unity 7.2.6
and
Linux  : 4.8.0-37-generic  Ubuntu 16.10 with Unity 7.5.0

### Additional Information

It is probably the issue mentioned in #13364, but since it is closed and mentions two seemingly unrelated issues I opted for opening this topic.

data.title: Disable soft wrap on mini editors
data.body:
### Requirements

* Filling out the template is required. Any pull request that does not include enough information to be reviewed in a timely manner may be closed at the maintainers' discretion.
* All new code requires tests to ensure against regressions

### Description of the Change

Don't soft wrap mini editors.  It seems like this isn't really useful for mini editors.

### Alternate Designs

There could be a separate programmatic toggle for mini editors that also looks at the global setting.

### Why Should This Be In Core?

Because mini editors already live in core!

### Benefits

No more "why can't I scroll right when I type something really long?"

### Possible Drawbacks

Some mini editors may be relying on this, though I think that would be bad practice considering it's a user setting.

### Applicable Issues

Fixes atom/tree-view#473

/cc @simurai

data.title: [Enhancement Requests] Package Sets/Lists
data.body:
[Enhancement Requests] Package Sets/Lists

It strikes me as painful and tedious with ALL editors like Atom, VSCode, Sublime, etc... that it is so hard to produce and share curated, reproducible sets of packages or total configurations.

The ability to do this, and make it simple to export, share, save and sync would be a boon to users on multiple machines as well as organizations or teams all trying to create a common platform to work from. 

Bonus points if these can be saved to Github in some fashion :)

data.title: [Beta 1.14.0] APM or github packages and Portable mode

Hi,
1> apm cannot be run from atom folder and need a complete path.
2> apm installs and "builds" the installed package in the not-portable user folder, for windows `C:\Users\myself\.atom`
My setup is somewhere on my D disk and works fine except that :-)
```
Windows 7 x64
Atom    : 1.14.0-beta4
Electron: 1.3.13

```
Thanks

data.title: Previously open session isn't being saved when opening atom from spotlight
data.body:
### Prerequisites

* [x] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

Previous open session isn't being saved when you open atom 

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Open a project from terminal via: `atom .`
2. close the window, not atom, but the window.  Open atom from the dock, should be a empty window.  
3. Close atom completely.  
4. Open the project from terminal again via `atom .`
5. completely close out of atom `cmd+q`
6. open atom from spotlight

NOTE: the issue we're seeing is,  ~/.atom/storage/application.json is saved when you switch context from Atom, but if you don't, it doesn't get updated.  When you close the atom window, but don't exit atom on mac, it sets the state to empty window, which is the last session. 


**Expected behavior:** [What you expect to happen]
Should open current session
**Actual behavior:** [What actually happens]
Opens blank window

**Reproduces how often:** [What percentage of the time does it reproduce?]
100% when you don't switch context
### Versions
```
atom --version
Atom    : 1.13.1
Electron: 1.3.13
Chrome  : 52.0.2743.82
Node    : 6.5.0

apm --version
apm  1.14.1
npm  3.10.5
node 4.4.5
python 2.7.10
git 2.10.1

```

data.title: Open empty editor as a pending pane item
data.body:
### Requirements

* Filling out the template is required. Any pull request that does not include enough information to be reviewed in a timely manner may be closed at the maintainers' discretion.
* All new code requires tests to ensure against regressions

### Description of the Change

If the `Open Empty Editor on Startup` option is checked, open it as a pending pane item.  This way, if you open a folder and then a file, it doesn't stick around.  However, if you just wanted to open Atom for some note-taking purposes, the existing behavior is not affected as the pending pane item will become non-pending as soon as you write something.  I've always been annoyed at having to manually close the untitled editor after I open a file.

### Alternate Designs

None.

### Why Should This Be In Core?

Already in core.

### Benefits

No longer have to manually close the Untitled tab after opening a folder.

### Possible Drawbacks

Maybe some people were relying on this?  Though Ctrl+N shouldn't be that bad.

### Applicable Issues

None that I could find.

data.title: Show first project path as window title if no pane items are open
data.body:
Fixes #13647.

This restores the behavior we had prior to #13475 when there are no pane items while preserving its improved behavior for paths outside of the current project.

data.title: The Reopen Projects menu is empty when atom is opened without a project
data.body:
### Prerequisites

* [x] Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
* [x]  Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
* [x] Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
* [x]  Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
* [x] Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

Unexpected restart causes Atom to lose project state

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Open Atom, go to settings -> core and unselect  `Reopen Previous Windows On Start`
2. Close Atom and open Atom from spotlight
3. Go to content menu and try to open recent projects.

**Expected behavior:** [What you expect to happen]
It has recent projects
**Actual behavior:** [What actually happens]
It's empty,  when you open a project, it gets populated. 

**Reproduces how often:** [What percentage of the time does it reproduce?]
100%

No Project loaded:
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/5624870/22668453/a47be014-ec75-11e6-990e-e43baf81b55b.png)



After opening a project:
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/5624870/22668474/b306971e-ec75-11e6-9e57-4eff8eef9ad9.png)


### Versions

```
atom --version
Atom    : 1.13.1
Electron: 1.3.13
Chrome  : 52.0.2743.82
Node    : 6.5.0

apm --version
apm  1.14.1
npm  3.10.5
node 4.4.5
python 2.7.10
git 2.10.1
```
### Additional Information

Any additional information, configuration or data that might be necessary to reproduce the issue.

data.title: Unexpected restart causes Atom to lose project state
data.body:
### Prerequisites

* [x] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

I'm currently grappling with a problem with my laptop where it restarts when resuming from sleep without an external power source.  This causes Atom to lose the project I was working on, and I have to reopen it.  The Reopen Projects menu is also empty, though it is populated once a folder is opened.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Open a folder in Atom
2. Somehow trigger an unexpected restart (I don't know if holding down the power button will work for this)
3. After restarting, reopen Atom

**Expected behavior:** The project to be displayed

**Actual behavior:** An empty editor with only an Untitled tab (if that option is enabled)

**Reproduces how often:** 100%

### Versions

```
Atom    : 1.15.0-dev-4eb3f22
Electron: 1.4.15
Chrome  : 53.0.2785.143
Node    : 6.5.0
```
```
apm  1.15.3
npm  3.10.5
node 4.4.5 x64
python 2.7.12
git 2.10.0.windows.1
visual studio 2015
```
Windows 10 x64.

### Additional Information

This may be related to #11406, though I have not been able to specifically reproduce that as 1) all open files are always saved before I put the laptop to sleep, and 2) there is no way for me to be typing in Atom when the restart occurs, as it happens as soon as Windows attempts to recover from sleep.
